title: 109_hr2951
content: The Act titled "Lifetime Pension Annuity for You Act of 2005" excludes lifetime income payments. The Act "Lifetime Pension Annuity for You Act of 2005" excludes 50% of lifetime income payments from gross income, up to $5,000 per year ($10,000 for joint returns). The Act "Lifetime Pension Annuity for You Act of 2005" excludes 25% of lifetime income payments from gross income under certain retirement plans, up to $5,000 per year ($10,000 for joint returns). The maximum exclusion for taxable years is $5,000 ($10,000 for joint returns) with a cost-of-living adjustment after 2006. The maximum exclusion for taxable years is $5,000 ($10,000 for joint returns) with a cost-of-living adjustment after 2006. Amounts not multiples of $100 are rounded down. Certain exceptions apply to defined benefit plans and annuity contracts. The maximum exclusion for taxable years is $5,000 ($10,000 for joint returns) with a cost-of-living adjustment after 2006. Exceptions apply to defined benefit plans and annuity contracts, including those after the death of the annuitant and joint annuitant, unless the beneficiary is the surviving spouse. An annuity contract can be a qualified funding asset without a qualified assignment. Lifetime income payments are defined as amounts received as an annuity under an annuity contract, where only the annuitant or joint annuitant is legally entitled to receive the payments during their lifetime. Lifetime income payments are received as an annuity under a contract where the annuitant or joint annuitant is entitled to receive payments over their lifetime in a series of substantially equal periodic payments. The annuitant and joint annuitant must meet certain requirements for annuity payments to be considered part of a series of substantially equal periodic payments. These requirements include a minimum period of payments or a minimum amount that must be paid, with exceptions for variations in payment amounts based on investment experience. The annuity payments can be adjusted due to various factors such as reallocations among investment options, actuarial gains or losses, cost of living indices, or changes in payment frequency. Lump sum withdrawals or modifications to payment duration can also impact the payment schedule. The annuity payments may be reduced for reasons such as a qualified domestic relations order or lower payments after the death of an annuitant or joint annuitant. The minimum period of payments for annuitant or joint annuitant is a guaranteed term that does not exceed 10 years or the life expectancy of the annuitant and joint annuitant as of the annuity starting date. For annuity contracts, the minimum period of payments is determined based on life expectancy tables provided by the Secretary. The minimum amount payable to the designated beneficiary is defined as a refund-like payment that ensures lifetime income payments. The minimum period of payments for annuity contracts is determined based on life expectancy tables.
